key_points: Over 100 million $600 stimulus payments were sent by IRS in January, approved by Congress.
Payments made through direct deposit, paper checks, or prepaid debit cards; 8 million debit cards were distributed.
IRS warns recipients to watch for the debit cards, as some may mistake them for junk mail.
Debit cards come in a white envelope with the Treasury Department seal, issued by MetaBank.
The card can be used for purchases, ATM withdrawals, and transferring funds without fees.
Individuals earning less than $75,000 and couples earning less than $150,000 are eligible for full payment.
Payment phases out at $87,000 for single filers and $174,000 for joint filers without children.
Undocumented immigrants without Social Security numbers ineligible, but their spouses and children can receive payments if they have SSNs.
Dependents, like some college students, are ineligible for the payments.
People can check payment status using the IRS's Get My Payment online tool.
